FacilityName: Fisher Scientific Co- Western Distribution Center
LEPC: City of Santa Clara Fire Dept.
RMPDescription: WDC- Santa Clara, CA - Federal Submittal

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:  The facility's overall approach and commitment to proper chemical management is demonstrated by training, procedures, and maintenance systems currently in place at the facility.  The facility is committed to ensuring safe operations in accordance with Part 68 requirements and has established a senior manager responsible for Part 68 implementation and compliance.

Source and Federal Regulated Substances Description:  The Western Distribution Center is located in Santa Clara, California.  The facility is a distribution center for laboratory equipment and laboratory-grade chemicals.  The facility is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68 due to onsite storage of chloroform and ethyl ether.  In addition, the facility is regulated under California's Accidental Release Prevention Program due to onsite storage of ammonia and hydrofluoric acid.  The one (1) regulated process at the facility is the storage of chemicals.  A review of numerous inventory data indicated that the facility had approximately 11,130 pounds of ethyl ether; 10,500 pounds of chloroform in storage.  The amount of chloroform differs from that amount listed in Section 1.17 of this document; the amount in Section 1.17 is the federal threshold quantity of 20,000 pounds for chloroform.  The facility predictively filed for chloroform in the event that the quantity of this material stored on site exceeds the threshold quantity over the next five years.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:  The facility has instituted procedures for the packing and labeling of chemicals to prevent releases.  In addition, new employees are trained on release procedures during new employee orientation.  Remaining employees receive refresher training on release procedures annually during emergency evacuation procedures and drill training.  Members of the facility's emergency response team also receive the required annual refre

sher training.

Five-Year Accident History:  The facility has had no RMP-reportable accidents or releases of ethyl ether or chloroform within the past five years.

Emergency Response Program:  The facility has instituted a facility emergency response team consisting of employees from various shifts.  The team has received training as described in 29 CFR 1910.120.  If a release were to occur that could not be handled by the team, the facility has contracted with an outside contractor, Onyx, for emergency response.  The facility has also coordinated response efforts with the City of Santa Clara Fire Department to ensure that the Department will respond as necessary.  The facility has established a notification mechanism to ensure that the Department will be properly notified when response is required for a release.  The facility submitted copies of its SARA 302, 311, and 312 reports to the Department.  The facility is subject to emergency response plan requirements including 29 CFR 1910.138 and 1910.120.  In addition, the facility is subject to the preparedness and prevention requirements of 40 CFR 265 Subpart C since the facility is a small quantity generator of hazardous waste.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Periodic reviews of the program, training, and maintenance procedures are conducted to ensure that any necessary and appropriate changes are made to maintain and improve safety.
